Class Fraction

java.lang.Object
Fraction
All Implemented Interfaces:
Comparable<Fraction>
public class Fraction extends Object implements Comparable<Fraction>
The Fraction class represents a rational number using a numerator and a denominator.

It supports arithmetic operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division), comparison, simplification, and conversion to both string and decimal representations.

The class implements Comparable to allow for sorting and ordering of fractions.

Note: This class does not handle exceptions for invalid input (e.g., zero denominator explicitly), but defaults the denominator to 1 if zero is provided. Example usage: 

     Fraction a = new Fraction(1, 2);
     Fraction b = new Fraction(3, 4);
     Fraction c = a.add(b);  // c is 5/4
     System.out.println(c); // prints "5/4"

      private int numerator
      The numerator of the fraction. Can be negative or zero.

      The denominator of the fraction. Always kept positive and never zero.

    • Fraction

      public Fraction(int num, int den)
      Constructs a Fraction with the given numerator and denominator. Simplifies the fraction automatically.
      Parameters:
      num - the numerator
      den - the denominator (if zero, will be reset to 1)

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Returns a string representation of the fraction. If the denominator is 1, returns just the numerator (as an integer). Otherwise, returns the fraction in the form "numerator/denominator".
      Overrides:
      toString in class Object
      Returns:
      a string representation of the fraction

    • compareTo

      public int compareTo(Fraction other)
      Compares two fractions. The result is zero if the fractions are equal. It returns a value less than 0 if this fraction is less than the fraction argument. It returns a value greater than 0 if this fraction is greater than the fraction argument.
      Specified by:
      compareTo in interface Comparable<Fraction>
      Parameters:
      other - the fraction to compare to
      Returns:
      the value 0 if the argument fraction is equal to this fraction; a value less than 0 if this fraction is less than the fraction argument; and a value greater than 0 if this fraction is greater than the fraction argument

      public boolean isNegative()

      Returns:

    • findGCD

      public static int findGCD(int a, int b)
      Computes the greatest common divisor (GCD) of two integers using the Euclidean algorithm. This method always returns a non-negative result.

      If either or both input integers are negative, their absolute values are used in the computation. The GCD of 0 and any non-zero integer is the absolute value of the non-zero integer. The GCD of 0 and 0 is defined here as 0.

      Parameters:
      a - the first integer (can be negative)
      b - the second integer (can be negative)
      Returns:
      the greatest common divisor of a and b, always non-negative
